1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1940
Where did you set up housekeeping? Godfrey, Boone County, Illinois
Where had you been living before that? Godfrey, Boone County, Illinois
For how many people did you prepare meals? 9
How far was it to your nearest store? 3 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? 3 weeks
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, sugar, butter, oatmeal, coffee, tea, salt, raisins, beans, dried apples & apricots, blueberries.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Flour
In what quantities did you buy it? Hundred pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.75
How much did you use Graham flour? Not any
Whole wheat flour? Not any
Was flour milled locally? Yes, far away? No, what year? 1947
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.60
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Not any
Wheat flour? Not any
Farina? Not any
Oats? Not any
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? By hand

Whole wheat flour looked much delicious than ordinary white flour for bread.
Jones, Mrs. A.E.

Muskegon Heights, Mich., 1902

In winter:
- **Breakfast:** Oatmeal, bread, fruit
- **Dinner:** Beef or mutton, bread, beans, butter, tea, preserves
- **Supper:** Meat, beans, fried potato, onion soup, often bread

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

The dinner was served hot, no oatmeal dinner, it was served by all.

We got the idea of making this from reading some of Charles Dickens' books that spoke about it.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Some of the flour was very dark and made heavy bread that was very bitter.

Also, some of the oatmeal was bitter. It was thought that the bitterness was because of the wheat or oats being too young.

Some was so bad that we could not get better except from work. We saved the bitter for feed for animals.

We used the wood for cooking. We had a fireplace for lighting, but sometimes when it was getting short we made some candles by tying a string into tallow.

We also tried to keep longer candles on hand.

When we were getting low on matches we twisted strips of paper into taper to light in the fire.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No.

Some of the flour was very dark & made heavy bread that was some bitter.

Also some of the oatmeal was bitter. It was thought that the bitterness was because of the wheat & oats having been frozen. Some was so bad that as soon as we could get better bought from Yorkshire we saved the bitter for feed for animals.

We used paraffin (or coal oil) in lamps & lanterns for lights, but one time when it was getting short we made some candles by dipping a string into tallow. We also tried to keep tallow candles on hand.

When we were getting low, our matches we twisted strips of paper into taper to light in the fire.
